Market cows 
 Ursula Nafula
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Everybody knew that Mama Schola liked
 to shout a lot. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 That day, it was about cows at the 
 market. 
 
 
 “Push these sily cows away,” she said. 
 “They are eating my vegetables.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 “Hey you there! Push these sily cows
 away from here,” she insisted. “They are
 
 eating my clothes.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 “Where is the owner of these sily cows?” 
 she shouted. “They are eating my grains.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Sorimpan, the herd boy, had just gone to
 drink water at a tap when his cows
 
 wandered of to the market. 
 
 He hid away, squating in fear, when he
 
 heard the shouting woman. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 “Now lok what these sily cows have 
 done!” she continued to shout. “They 
 
 have broken my beautiful pots.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 A short time later, “Aah! Not again!” she
 
 was heard saying. “I wil report this
 mater to the police. These sily cows
 have knocked down my fruit stand.”
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Sorimpan finaly came out stick in hand, 
 
 dodged betwen the gathering crowds 
 and managed to get a clear view of his 
 cows. 
 
 Sorimpan’s cows knew him wel so they 
 turned and loked up at him as he 
 
 apeared! 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 At this point, the big crowd of onlokers 
 
 of men, women and even children al 
 stared at the cows which paid atention 
 only to Sorimpan. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Sudenly, the cows broke their silence!
 They began to talk al at the same time,
 
 criticising the people! 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The crowds were shocked and steped back one by one, 
 afraid of the cows. 
 
 
 Then the cows stoped talking and watched the crowd in 
 amazement! 
 
 
 But Mama Schola was heard saying, “Since when did cows 
 medle in our market busineses?” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 It was Mama Schola’s turn to be 
 
 criticised by the cows! 
 Al the other women seling moved to 
 stand with Mama Schola out of fear. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 12  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The cows criticised the women, 
 
 comenting on the state of their
 vegetables, saying, 
 “What kind of vegetables are these? They
 
 are al old and drying up!” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 13  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 It was clear that the cows were not yet 
 done! 
 
 They turned round and faced the cloth- 
 stand and shouted, “You say we eat your 
 clothes, what clothes? You mean these 
 
 old rugs! Who wil buy them?” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 14  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The cows then moved to the next stand 
 and everybody folowed them with their 
 
 eyes. 
 “Your grains are ful of wevils. Who 
 wants to eat that! We only tasted to se 
 
 if this is a place to come more often!” the 
 cows snered. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 15  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 “And you Mama Schola,” the cows 
 continued, “stop making noise. You talk
 of these cracked pots?” The cows turned
 
 their heads towards Mama Schola’s pots.
 “They are no god, they break so easily,
 so don’t blame us.” 
 
 
 With that, the cows turned and left,
 
 folowed closely by Sorimpan.
